Hello! My name is Emily Wilson, and I'm a licensed psychotherapist specializing in cognitive-behavioral therapy. I have over 8 years of experience working with individuals dealing with various mental health concerns, including anxiety, depression, and relationship issues. I'm committed to providing a safe, non-judgmental space for you to explore your thoughts and feelings.

Could you please tell me what brings you here today? What are the reasons that led you to seek therapy at this time?

I... I don't know if I should be here. It's just that lately, I've been having trouble sleeping and eating. Food doesn't taste good anymore, and I've lost my appetite. My friend's birthday party is coming up, and usually, I'd be excited to try all the new dishes she's preparing, but now... nothing really appeals to me.

It takes a lot of courage to acknowledge that something's not quite right and to take this first step. I'm here to support you without judgment. It sounds like you're experiencing some significant changes in your daily life, especially with sleep and appetite. 

Can you tell me more about what's been going on with your sleep? How long have you been having trouble sleeping, and has it been affecting your energy levels or mood during the day?

I'd rather not talk about my sleep right now... Can we talk about something else? Like, I've just been feeling really restless lately. I find myself getting up and walking around the room for no reason, or switching between tasks without finishing anything. It's like I have all this excess energy, but at the same time, I'm exhausted. Does that make any sense?

It can feel overwhelming to discuss certain topics, and we can definitely come back to sleep later when you're ready.

I want to acknowledge that it sounds like you're experiencing a really confusing mix of feelings - restlessness, excess energy, but also exhaustion. That can be really frustrating and hard to understand, even for yourself. It does make sense in the context of what you've shared so far, especially with the changes in appetite and lack of interest in things that usually bring you joy.

Can you help me understand more about this restlessness? What do you think might be driving it? Is there something on your mind that's making you feel this way, or does it seem to come out of nowhere?

(sigh) Honestly... I don't know. It just feels like everything is bothering me lately. Little things that never used to get to me are now really frustrating. And it's not just the big things in life, but tiny stuff too... like a messy room or someone cutting me off in traffic. (pauses) It's all just so... annoying.

It can feel really overwhelming when everything seems to be getting under your skin. It's like your patience and tolerance have been worn down, and even small things are now magnified.

I want to explore this feeling of "everything is bothering me" a bit more. When you say that little things are frustrating you, what do you think is the worst part about them? Is it the inconvenience, the principle of the matter, or something else entirely? For example, when someone cuts you off in traffic, what goes through your mind in that moment?

(pauses, looking slightly frustrated) Honestly, I don't know... It just feels like people are being so careless and inconsiderate. Like, can't they see I'm trying to get somewhere too? (shakes head) But at the same time, it's not even about them, really. It's like... I'm already on edge, and then something like that happens, and it just tips me over. (trails off, looking uncertain) Does that make sense?

It makes a lot of sense, actually. It sounds like you're feeling really sensitive and reactive right now, and even small things can trigger a big emotional response. It's like your emotional cup is already full, and then something else comes along and overflows it.

I want to gently explore this idea that people are being "careless and inconsiderate." What do you think would happen if people were more considerate and careful? Would that somehow make you feel better, or solve some underlying issue for you? In other words, what is it that you're really hoping for when you wish people would be more thoughtful?

(shakes head) I don't know... I guess I just wish things could go back to normal. You know, like they were a few months ago. Before... (pauses, looking uncomfortable) before my mom passed away. Everything's just felt off since then. (looks down, fidgeting with hands)

(I offer a gentle, empathetic nod) Oh, I'm so sorry to hear about your loss. Losing someone close to us can be one of the most painful experiences we go through. It's completely understandable that you're feeling like things are "off" since then.

It takes a lot of courage to acknowledge the impact of your mom's passing on your life. Can you tell me more about what you mean by "things could go back to normal"? What specifically do you think would need to happen for you to feel like things are back on track? Is it related to your emotions, your daily routine, or something else entirely?

(I lean forward slightly, showing I'm fully present and engaged in the conversation)

(looks up, eyes welling up with tears) I... I don't know. I just feel so lost without her. She was always the one who knew how to make me feel better when I was down. And now she's gone, and it feels like nothing can fill that void. (pauses, taking a deep breath) I guess what I mean by "normal" is feeling like myself again. Feeling like I can wake up in the morning and not feel this... this heaviness inside me. (trails off, struggling to find the words)

(looks down, fidgeting with hands again) It's just hard to explain. Everything feels different now. Even little things, like going home after work or cooking dinner... it all feels empty and pointless without her. (pauses, collecting thoughts) I don't know how to get back to being me, I guess. The me I was before she passed away.

(I offer a gentle, empathetic nod, and my voice is soft and supportive) Oh, I'm so sorry you're feeling this way. It's completely understandable that you're struggling to find your footing without your mom. She sounds like an incredibly important person in your life, and her absence has left a huge void.

(I pause for a moment, letting you process your emotions) It takes a lot of courage to admit when we're feeling lost and unsure of how to move forward. I want you to know that I'm here to support you, and we can work through this together.

(I lean forward slightly, showing I'm fully present and engaged in the conversation) You mentioned that everything feels "empty and pointless" without your mom. Can you tell me more about what you mean by that? Is it that you're feeling a lack of purpose or meaning in your daily activities, or is it more that you're just not enjoying the things you used to enjoy?

(I also make a gentle note) We've talked about sleep, appetite, and restlessness earlier. How are you taking care of yourself physically during this difficult time? Are there any changes you've noticed in your social interactions or relationships with others since your mom passed away?

It seems like I mistakenly repeated the therapist's response instead of providing a continuation of the patient's dialogue.

Let me try again:

(I take a deep breath, trying to gather my thoughts) It's just that... everything feels so different without her. Even simple things like cooking dinner or watching TV feel empty because she's not there to share them with me. I keep expecting her to call me or come over, and then I remember that she's really gone. (pauses, fighting back tears)

It's hard to explain, but it feels like a part of me is missing. Like, I'm just going through the motions of daily life without any real purpose or direction. I feel lost and alone, even when I'm around other people. (looks down, fidgeting with hands) I don't know how to get back to feeling like myself again. I don't know how to fill this void that's been left by her passing.

(I offer a gentle, empathetic nod, and my voice is soft and supportive) It sounds like you're experiencing a deep sense of grief and disconnection from the life you knew with your mom. It's as if her presence was a thread that wove through every aspect of your daily life, and now that she's gone, everything feels frayed and uncertain.

(I pause for a moment, letting you process your emotions) I want to acknowledge how painful it must be to feel like you're just going through the motions without any real purpose or direction. It's like you're navigating a familiar landscape, but all the landmarks and reference points are gone.

(I lean forward slightly, showing I'm fully present and engaged in the conversation) Can you tell me more about what you mean by "feeling like myself again"? What specific aspects of yourself do you feel are missing or lost since your mom passed away? Is it your sense of humor, your creativity, your confidence, or something else entirely?

(I also make a gentle note) You mentioned feeling lost and alone even when you're around other people. Have you noticed any changes in your relationships with friends or family members since your mom's passing? Are there any people in your life who have been particularly supportive or helpful during this difficult time?

(sighs, looking down) I think it's my confidence, mostly. My mom always knew how to make me feel better about myself, even when I was struggling. She had this way of believing in me that made me believe in myself too. Without her, I just feel really uncertain and self-doubting all the time.

(pauses, collecting thoughts) And yeah, my relationships with others have changed. I mean, people try to be supportive, but they don't really get it. They'll say things like "time heals all wounds" or "she's in a better place," but it just feels like they're not listening to me. They're not hearing how lost and scared I am.

(looks up, eyes welling up with tears again) My friends will try to plan things with me, like going out for dinner or seeing a movie, but it all just feels so... forced. Like we're trying to pretend that everything is okay when it's really not. And my family... we're all just trying to navigate this grief together, I guess. But it's hard when we're all feeling so lost and alone.

(trails off, struggling to find the words) I don't know, it's just like... my mom was always the one who held our family together, you know? And now that she's gone, it feels like we're all just drifting apart.

(I offer a gentle, empathetic nod, and my voice is soft and supportive) It sounds like your mom played a really unique and important role in your life, and her absence has left a huge void. Not only did she provide emotional support and validation, but she also seemed to be the glue that held your family together.

(I pause for a moment, letting you process your emotions) I want to acknowledge how painful it must be to feel like you're drifting apart from your loved ones during this already difficult time. It's like you're all trying to navigate this uncharted territory without a map or a compass.

(I lean forward slightly, showing I'm fully present and engaged in the conversation) You mentioned that people try to be supportive, but they don't really get it. What do you think would help them understand what you're going through? Is there something specific you wish they could know or do to support you better?

(I also make a gentle note) You talked about feeling uncertain and self-doubting without your mom's presence. Are there any memories or moments that you shared with her that still feel vivid and alive for you? Any moments that might help you tap into that sense of confidence and self-belief that she helped you cultivate?

(And, if I may add, we've been exploring your emotions, relationships, and sense of identity. How have you been taking care of your physical health during this time? Have you noticed any changes in your energy levels, appetite, or sleep patterns that might be related to your grief?)

I wake up feeling exhausted and drained. My appetite is also gone, and I've lost weight without even trying to. It's like my body is just going through the motions, but it's not really taking care of itself.

(I look up, eyes welling up with tears again) Sorry, it's just hard to talk about all this. It feels like everything is falling apart, and I don't know how to put the pieces back together again.
